report_title: Online Eyeglasses & Contact Lens Sales in the US
executive_summary: The Online Eyeglasses and Contact Lens Sales industry has experienced significant growth over the past five years. Industry revenue growth has been supported by rising e-commerce sales as consumers make the shift to online retailers for convenience and cost savings. More notably, innovative technologies have been introduced into the industry, such as augmented reality which allows consumers to try on frames virtually. This technology has allowed online retailers to more closely replicate the traditional in-person shopping experience. Moreover, the industry's growth was furthered by the coronavirus as consumers flocked to online retailers amid store closures and safety concerns. In all, industry revenue is expected to increase at a CAGR of 10.5% to $1.5 billion over the past five years, including an expected increase of 4.3% in 2023 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Industry revenue expected to increase at CAGR of 10.5% to $1.5 billion over past 5 years
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The industry revenue is expected to increase at a CAGR of 10.5% to $1.5 billion over the past five years, including an increase of 4.3% in 2023 alone when profit is expected to reach 5.7%.

While the total number of eyeglasses sold declined in 2020, largely a result of economic uncertainty related to the coronavirus, the share of online eyewear purchasing furthered, as consumers continued to fulfill demand for eyewear online. As economic conditions improved, pent-up demand caused industry revenue to skyrocket in 2021.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Industry revenue forecast to grow at CAGR of 2.0% to $1.6 billion over next 5 years
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Industry revenue is forecast to grow at a CAGR of 2.0% to $1.6 billion over the five years to 2028 when profit is expected to drop to 5.2%. While growth is forecast to be more moderate in the outlook period, e-commerce optical sales are slated to comprise a growing share of total optical sales as consumers increasingly feel comfortable purchasing industry products online.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Increased Vision Issues Will Support Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Because older demographics are the largest market for the industry because of the increasing prevalence of vision issues with age, an aging population increases demand for industry products. Furthermore, rising screen time usage will also support demand for corrective eyewear, including higher margin items, such as blue light-blocking lenses, in the outlook period.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Innovative Technologies Will Continue to Attract Customers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the next five years, the advent of new technologies will enable more online retailers to attract consumers. New digital experiences, largely featuring augmented reality (AR) and artificial intelligence (AI) software, will support growth as consumers seek more interactive and innovative online shopping experiences.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A Growing Telehealth Industry Will Fuel Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Services from the growing telehealth industry will be incorporated into the Online Eyeglasses and Contact Lens Sales industry over the next five years. Telehealth companies offer basic vision screenings via their website to help patients identify areas of concern. These online eye exams make it easy for consumers to quickly and conveniently renew prescriptions, offering a strong selling point for industry retailers.

industry_definition: This industry sells optical and eyewear goods over the internet. Merchandise is generally purchased from domestic (and in some cases international) manufacturers and wholesalers before being sold to the public.
key_trends: Many online retailers have strengthened their customer service to mitigate competition
Many elderly individuals have aimed to cut costs, thus stimulating demand for industry operators
The trend of new internet retailers entering the industry has been slightly slowed by acquisition activity
More online retailers are anticipated to invest in word-of-mouth marketing to drive consumer purchases
Many online retailers are anticipated to enhance their virtual try-on services
Legislation could put a significant strain on operators' cost savings and restrict industry revenue growth
Innovative digital platforms have supported industry growth

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment includes individuals aged 55 and older and accounts for the largest share of industry revenue due to vision deteriorating with age.
This segment includes individuals aged 35 to 54 and makes up the second-largest share of industry revenue as vision issues become more present in this age group.
This segment includes individuals aged 20 to 34 who demand on-trend eyeglasses.
This segment includes individuals aged 19 and younger who are the main buyers of non-prescription eyeglasses.

products_and_services.product_description: Contact lenses including soft contact lenses, rigid gas permeable contact lenses, extended wear contact lenses and disposable contact lenses.
All prescription glasses and lenses including single-vision lenses, multifocal lenses, prism lenses and any other lens requiring a prescription.
Over-the-counter reading glasses, blue light-blocking glasses and other nonprescription eyeglasses.

tier_1_suppliers: Glasses & Contacts Wholesaling in the US (/ibisworld/reportkey/1/931)
Wholesale Trade Agents and Brokers in the US (/ibisworld/reportkey/1/2100)
tier_2_suppliers: Long-Distance Freight Trucking in the US (/ibisworld/reportkey/1/1150)
Glasses & Contact Lens Manufacturing in the US (/ibisworld/reportkey/1/882)

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The aging population, economic conditions, price and fashion trends, as well as internet accessibility influence the frequency, quality and type of eyewear purchased.
Changes in fashion and technology are also important demand determinants for the industry.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Domestic operators in this industry supply both the domestic and international market through online websites.
However, trade in goods supplied by retail industries is accounted for at the manufacturing level.
Therefore, the level of import and export activity at the retail level is low and steady.

business_locations.location_description: The West is the largest region by industry establishment. California is the largest state in the region, home to technology hubs that attract online retailers. The region's consumers also have higher disposable incomes.
The Southeast is the second-largest region by establishment. Its dense population provides a large customer base. Florida is the largest state, with many older consumers requiring eyewear.
The Mid-Atlantic is the third-largest region by establishment. It has well-established transportation networks and is home to key trading ports, attracting operators with import supply chains.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) regulates eyeglasses and contact lenses as medical devices under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FDCA). Because online eyeglasses and contact lens sellers handle customers' private health information, they must adhere to numerous laws and regulations regarding privacy, security, and data protection. This may also affect the labeling, packaging, storage, servicing, marketing, and promotion of these items.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement is a significant regulation affecting the Online Eyeglasses and Contacts Sales industry. This agreement minimizes the administrative burden on businesses that collect sales tax across multiple states. The tax collection move threatens the industry as it might eliminate the cost-saving advantage of being online.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Fairness to Contact Lens Consumers Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: Implemented in 2003, the Fairness to Contact Lens Consumers Act (FCLCA) sets a national standard for eye care practitioners and direct marketers regarding the release and verification of consumer contact lens prescriptions. Online sellers must request prescription verification before shipping orders and comply with rules that provide patients a copy of their prescriptions post-fitting. The FCLCA also allows states to set prescription length, as long as it exceeds a year.

The Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) is a federal regulation that affects all US industries, including the Online Eyeglasses and Contacts Sales industry. The FLSA sets rules for minimum wage, overtime pay, and child labor that businesses need to follow.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Operators must adhere to labor, safety laws and FDA regulations for selling medical products.
Start-up costs can be significant for purchasing inventory and equipment, but lower for e-commerce without brick-and-mortar locations.
New entrants struggle against established brand recognition, needing to differentiate through superior service or niche products.

basis_points.basis_title: Price, product selection, innovation and availability
basis_points.basis_description: Competition in the Online Eyeglasses and Contact Lens Sales industry is principally based on price, product selection, innovation and availability as well as customer service.
Larger online retailers compete based on having an extensive product portfolio, which may appeal to consumers who want particular brand-name products.
Larger companies may have the financial resources necessary to invest in direct marketing of contact lenses, which intensifies competition for industry operators.
Online retailers may compete with their customer service, which is an integral component in driving repeat customer sales.

Over the next five years, many online retailers will likely increase investment to enhance their websites to become more user-friendly and enhance consumers' digital shopping experiences, thereby increasing competition.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Mix of small to large players
concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry has a mix of small, medium and large companies, with larger companies holding significant market share but smaller/mid-sized companies accounting for a substantial portion.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Economies of scale for larger players
concentration_points.concentration_description: Larger companies can gain competitive advantage by utilizing economies of scale to increase operating efficiencies and profit.
Smaller companies differentiate themselves by offering niche products or specialized services to compete with larger players.
Differentiation strategies like competitive pricing, unique products and superior service contribute to moderate market share concentration.
Many companies have specialized product lines targeting specific demographics or needs, further contributing to moderate concentration.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases Are The Largest Expense Category For The Industry
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases are expected to account for 51.6% of industry revenue in 2023. This expense includes the cost of buying, warehousing, distributing, shipping and handling the product. Fluctuations in raw material costs, though accounting for a small share of purchase costs, can affect the price that retailers must pay for goods.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: For example, as the price of plastic rises, a key input commodity for eyeglass frames, online retailers contend with higher purchase costs related to obtaining industry products from manufacturers.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The Online Eyeglasses and Contact Lens Sales industry exhibits a low level of capital intensity. In 2023, for every dollar spent on wages, the industry incurs an estimated $0.03 in capital expenditures. Capital-related costs include warehouse space, computer equipment and distribution expenditures. Additionally, online eyeglasses and contact lens retailers have capital costs from purchasing a domain name and a website hosting provider. To maintain their websites and protect consumers from fraud, online retailers need to purchase and maintain computers, printers and software programs such as electronic payment programs and firewalls.

Comparatively, wage costs include hiring contracted website designers. Other jobs include website maintenance and order fulfillment. While labor costs for the industry are relatively low, the industry has a low level of capital intensity because capital expenditures are much lower than they would be for brick-and-mortar eyeglasses and contact lens stores.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The rapid expansion of e-commerce has increased volatility.
Industry revenue fluctuates in line with changes in consumers' disposable income and their vision insurance coverage, which have both been consistently high during the five-year period.

To attract consumers, many online retailers have developed a product portfolio of eyeglasses and contact lenses that are price-competitive compared with brick-and-mortar retailers. They have also expanded software that enhances consumers' digital shopping experiences, such as virtual try-on services, to attract consumers even during times of economic instability.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The development, penetration and use of the internet are central to the Online Eyeglasses and Contact Lens Sales industry. Additionally, the declining cost of computer processing power continues to have a large effect in the ease with which e-commerce business is conducted. Some of the basic requirements for an electronic retailer are a selling platform, hardware and the related software associated with it. Online stores have websites that display the nature of the company, the services or goods provided and their price. Another crucial element is the establishment of an application process that facilitates payment transactions, either by credit card or electronic funds transfer.

The internet, online commerce and online advertising markets are characterized by rapidly changing technologies, evolving industry standards, frequent new product and service introductions and changing customer preferences. The advent of standardized disposable soft contact lenses, along with the Fairness to Contact Lens Consumers Act's prescription portability requirement, have enabled contact lens sales to be unbundled from the fitting process, enabling consumers to choose among several retail channels to buy their replacement lenses. This factor illustrates the importance of technological development to the industry's performance and viability.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or do you retail a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Most companies in this industry sell glasses and contacts

FAQs.question: Does your company have a diversified client base, or are sales heavily dependent on one market (consumers, businesses, government)?
FAQs.answer: Online eyewear retailers mainly sell to individual consumers

FAQs.question: What steps does your company take to retain talented employees with specialized knowledge?
FAQs.answer: Labor requirements for this industry are relatively low

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in order to expand its reach and reduce its overhead expenses?
FAQs.answer: The largest companies in this industry have grown by acquiring small players

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Internet retailers often have low labor requirements

FAQs.question: How has your company adapted its operations to account for the rise of online sales over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Some companies have offered tools that allow customers to virtually try on glasses

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Contact lenses and glasses must meet health standards to avoid potential harm to customers

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Industry companies work with trade groups for online retailers and eyewear stores

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: Profit for this industry has increased over the past five years as demand for e-commerce has skyrocketed.

FAQs.question: How have volatile input prices affected profit margins over the past year?
FAQs.answer: Volatile input costs for the manufacturing of glasses and contacts can affect profit margins for retailers as manufacturers will pass on cost savings or cost increases.

FAQs.question: How quickly can new technology be adopted? Does your company keep up to date with the latest technology?
FAQs.answer: Companies must quickly adopt new technology, particularly with software enhancements that improve the search capabilities of their websites.

FAQs.question: How can you improve your company to receive better word-of-mouth recommendations? How many of your clients were referred to you by a satisfied client?
FAQs.answer: Having a good reputation and receiving positive word-of-mouth recommendations from customers is important given the medical nature of industry products.

FAQs.question: How can you increase customer traffic on your website?
FAQs.answer: Companies should be easily accessible to customers via the internet and should readily provide customer service.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your customers pay for services with private health insurance? How do the rest of your customers pay?
FAQs.answer: A significant proportion of optical care is funded by private health and vision insurance. Therefore, an increase in the number of people with private health insurance will likely lead to more optometrist visits.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand due to rising disposable income levels? How do you stimulate demand when disposable income levels are low?
FAQs.answer: As per capita disposable income rises, more consumers are able to purchase high-cost, brand-name products.

FAQs.question: Do your services implement technology that appeals to internet users? How do you boost consumer confidence in purchasing your products online?
FAQs.answer: This industry is sensitive to the number of broadband connections. Additionally, increased computer and internet usage is likely to raise consumer confidence in purchasing products online, thereby stimulating demand for industry products from online retailers.
